awd_titl_txt: Sustaining Wyoming's Advancing Reach in Mathematics and Science (SWARMS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Sustaining Wyoming's Advancing Reach in Mathematics and Science (SWARMS) is certifying seventy (70) new mathematics and science teachers over a 5-year period (2014-2019). SWARMS is a Noyce, Phase I, collaboration project joining four distinct groups to enhance Wyoming's pool of mathematics and science teachers. The four groups include: 1) The University of Wyoming (UW) among the College of Arts & Sciences (A&S), College of Education, and the UW Science and Mathematics Teaching Center; 2) Northwest College, 3) Military partners including: UW Office of Veteran Services, Francis Warren Air Force Base, Wyoming National Guard, and Wyoming Air National Guard; and 4) High-need partner school districts including: Big Horn, Fremont, Goshen, Laramie, Hot Springs, Natrona, Uinta, and Washakie. 

SWARMS leverages and extends existing UW collaborations with the Wyoming Department of Education, community colleges, military partners, and high-need partner school districts. Responding to Wyoming's critical need to dramatically enhance the number and quality of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) teachers in high-poverty, low-performing schools, SWARMS is expanding the post-baccalaureate program to engage military veterans and holders of STEM graduate and undergraduate degrees. SWARMS targets mathematics, chemistry, earth science, and physics graduates.

SWARMS provides Noyce scholarships or stipends to undergraduates and graduates to support the development of seventy teachers with strong STEM backgrounds as a result of military experience or baccalaureate degrees in a STEM discipline, as well as obtainment of a secondary teaching certificate. SWARMS is iteratively testing new recruitment strategies, reorienting post-baccalaureate teacher certification classes, nurturing a community cohort model, and implementing best practices in early career mentoring programs while targeting a diverse candidate population. Up to twelve hours of post-baccalaureate work towards certification can be applied to a master's program in Curriculum and Instruction in UW's College of Education. These seventy Noyce Scholars are mentored in the first few years of their teaching careers by previous Noyce Scholars.  In addition, they are supported by yearly cohort meetings, on-site visitations, community-based blog interactions, face-to-face interactions, and electronic newsletter spotlights and distribution. 

The 5-year goals of SWARMS include: 1) Engage and nurture the UW community of scholars as partners in filling the STEM pipeline's demand for highly qualified science and mathematics teachers in high need secondary schools; 2) Recruit a diverse group of talented military veterans and individuals who hold graduate and undergraduate STEM degrees; 3) Prepare 70 highly qualified, Wyoming certified, secondary science and mathematics teachers to teach rigorous content through inquiry-driven approaches steeped in integrated STEM; 4) Strengthen and expand innovative programs (post-bac) and test new recruitment techniques for targeted prospective teachers; 5) Promote science and mathematics teacher retention in high need schools by developing learning communities to support cohort groups based on best practices in early career teacher mentoring; and 6) Study and iteratively build SWARMS for sustainability, replication, and dissemination.

SWARMS, Sustaining Wyoming's Advancing Reach in Mathematics and Science, is committed to certifying future mathematics and science teachers of Wyoming in order to sustain growth and build upon local STEM talent to develop future generations of STEM-literate youth.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
As of December 2021, Sustaining Wyoming's Advancing Reach in Mathematics and Science (SWARMS) at the University of Wyoming (UWyo) had recruited 57 scholars (51 obtained STEM teaching certification), and six scholars were still seeking certification. Over the years (2013-2022), the SWARMS team worked to utilize the chatroom (a virtual platform for communication), maintain efforts for recruitment (partnering with other colleges on campus), offer professional development (PD) to pre- and in-service SWARMS teachers (every summer and continuing in the future), guide post-bac graduate certificate program revisions for secondary certification, and provide current STEM content and research driven pedagogies (in coursework and outreach activities). The SWARMS cohorts were strong, and some members of each cohort can be viewed on seven seven publicly accessible videos (see UWswarms.org). Publications from educational research focusing on integrated STEM, partnerships, and science education are results from years of work with SWARMS pre/in-service teachers.

One example of a SWARMS teacher is Mr. Josh Larson, a UW SWARMS Scholar graduate, who is highlighted on the NSF Noyce page: https://www.nsfnoyce.org/profiles/larson-joshua/

For Goal 1 and Goal 5, SWARMS utilized the chatroom as well as offered community opportunities throughout the life of the grant as appropriate. Goal (1): engage and nurture the UW community of scholars to be partners in filling STEM pipeline's need for highly qualified science and mathematics teachers in high need K-12 schools, and Goal (5): promote science and mathematics teacher retention in high need schools by developing learning communities to support cohort groups based on best practices in early-career teacher mentoring.

SWARMS videos and recruitment efforts focused on Goal 2 and 3 (see UWswarms.org). The SWARMS team actively engaged veteran groups and promoted research driven integrated STEM content and pedagogies. Goal (2): recruit a diverse group of talented military veterans and individuals who hold graduate and undergraduate STEM degrees, and Goal (3): prepare at least fourteen highly qualified, Wyoming certified, K-12 science and mathematics teachers annually to teach rigorous content through inquiry-driven approaches steeped in integrated STEM.

Professional Development (PD) offerings allowed SWARMS to reach Goal 4 and 5. The PD offerings ranged from short term content engagement to long term (multi-year) research opportunities. The SWARMS program was the lead for the Western Regional Noyce Alliance (WRNA) subaward and worked closely with others in Colorado to present six PD opportunities over the last three years. Goal (4): strengthen and expand innovative programs (post-bac) and test new recruitment techniques for targeted prospective teachers, and Goal (5): promote science and mathematics teacher retention in high need schools by developing learning communities to support cohort groups based on best practices in early-career teacher mentoring.

For Goal 6, the Post-bac Graduate Certificate program revisions were finalized for phase 1. All courses are available online and are being aligned with course objectives. The next phase is focusing on alternate pathways (such as micro-credentials and competency-based education) for graduate certificate student certification. Goal (6): study and iteratively build SWARMS for sustainability, replication, and dissemination. As such, SWARMS is unique in targeting and recruiting physics, chemistry, Earth science, and mathematics candidates, comprised of experienced military veterans and STEM graduates dedicated to Wyoming.

In general:

Highlights: Videos of SWARMS cohort members can be found at http://www.uwswarms.org/ (all cohorts).

Public Resources: The Data Corral is publicly available: https://datacorral.uwyo.edu/. Additionally, resources (look under *Educator Resources*) can be found on https://www.uwyo.edu/wycs/.

Dissemination: Peer-reviewed, ranked journal publications involving SWARMS participants were published adding evidence of new ideas to the field relating to partnerships, science education, and integrated STEM.

Sustainability: The SWARMS project concluded with sustainable changes to the post-bac graduate certificate program including online instruction and the alignment of courses and objectives. Professional developments were offered during SWARMS to participants and will continue (some of these are available at https://www.uwyo.edu/wycs/).

Reporting: The external evaluator report of the SWARMS project stated that "the SWARMS program has been successful in preparing and supporting post-bac individuals wanting to pursue a career in teaching. Participants consistently express appreciation for the program, the program PI, and [UWyo] for providing the opportunity. Graduates of SWARMS and currently enrolled participants value their experience with the program....."

Overall, the SWARMS team and pre/in-service teachers made impact and created a sustainable environment for STEM teacher nurturing and support in Wyoming and beyond. PI Burrows and CoPIs Slater, Dale, Jafari, and Northrup regularly engaged future, current, and past STEM scholars. The team recognized that connections to SWARMS and resources from the SWARMS community were (and are) crucial to budling Wyoming's teaching base. The University of Wyoming is dedicated to serving the constituents of the state, as the four-year land-grant institution. The SWARMS project is an example of this land grant mission. The educational research publications from the grant allow for feedback and growth of the entire science education, STEM integration, and partnership research community. 


Last Modified: 03/31/2022
Modified by: Andrea C Burrows
